title: Mrs. Johnson: A Case of Alzheimer Disease with Associated Mobility Issues
clinical_history: Mrs. Johnson is an 82-year-old retired librarian who was diagnosed with Alzheimer Disease (AD) 5 years ago. She has been experiencing progressive cognitive decline, including memory loss, difficulty with problem-solving, and changes in mood and behavior. Over the past year, her family has noticed a significant decline in her physical function, including difficulty with walking, balance, and transfers. She requires assistance with most daily activities, including bathing, dressing, and feeding. She has also been experiencing frequent falls, with the most recent fall occurring 2 weeks ago, resulting in a visit to the emergency department.
picture: A 24-hour picture of Mrs. Johnson's daily activities, including her sleep patterns, meals, and physical activities.
easing_factors: rest, lying down, and physical therapy interventions
past_history: Mrs. Johnson has a history of osteoporosis, with a previous fracture of her distal radius 10 years ago. She has also been experiencing urinary incontinence over the past 5 years.
medical_history: Alzheimer Disease (diagnosed 5 years ago), osteoporosis, and urinary incontinence
medications: Donepezil 10mg daily, memantine 10mg twice daily, calcium and vitamin D supplements, and oxybutynin 5mg twice daily
personal_history: Mrs. Johnson is a widow and lives with her daughter, who provides full-time care. She has two adult children and four grandchildren. She enjoys reading, gardening, and spending time with her family, but has had to give up these activities due to her declining health.
imaging: Recent X-rays of her hips and knees show joint space narrowing and osteopenia, consistent with osteoporosis.
